diseases.name: Acne
diseases.description: Acne is a common skin condition where the pores of your skin clog. Pore blockages produce blackheads, whiteheads, and other types of pimples. Pimples are pus-filled, sometimes painful, bumps on your skin. The medical term for acne is acne vulgaris.
diseases.symptoms:
Symptoms of acne on your skin include:

    Pimples (pustules): Pus-filled bumps (papules).
    Papules: Small, discolored bumps, often red to purple or darker than your natural skin tone.
    Blackheads: Plugged pores with a black top.
    Whiteheads: Plugged pores with a white top.
    Nodules: Large lumps under your skin that are painful.
    Cysts: Painful fluid-filled (pus) lumps under your skin.
diseases.treatment: There are several ways to treat acne. A healthcare provider might recommend taking oral medications, using topical medications, or using medicated therapies. The goal of treatment is to stop new pimples from forming and heal existing blemishes.

diseases.name: Carcinoma
diseases.description: Carcinoma is a type of cancer that begins in the skin or the tissues that line or cover internal organs. It is the most common type of cancer.
diseases.symptoms: Symptoms depend on the type and location of the carcinoma but may include lumps, sores, or abnormal growths on the skin or within internal organs.
diseases.treatment: Treatment options for carcinoma vary based on the type, location, and severity. They can include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and targeted therapy.

diseases.name: Eczema
diseases.description: Eczema is a condition that causes your skin to become dry, itchy, and bumpy. This condition weakens your skinâ€™s barrier function, which helps your skin retain moisture and protects your body from outside elements. Eczema is a type of dermatitis.
treatment: Use gentle or sensitive skin moisturizers throughout the day.
Apply topical medications like steroids as advised by your provider.
Take oral medications such as anti-inflammatory medicines, antihistamines, or corticosteroids.
Use immunosuppressant drugs to help regulate your immune system.
Consider light therapy to improve skin appearance.
Avoid triggers that cause eczema flare-ups.

diseases.name: Keratosis
diseases.description: Keratosis is a skin condition where excess keratin builds up in the skin, resulting in rough, scaly patches. These patches may be caused by sun exposure, aging, or genetics.
diseases.symptoms: Symptoms of keratosis include rough, scaly patches on the skin, particularly in areas that are frequently exposed to the sun. They can vary in color from white to brown.
diseases.treatment: Treatment options include cryotherapy (freezing), topical medications to reduce keratin buildup, and laser therapy to remove damaged skin cells.

diseases.name: Milia
diseases.description: Milia are small, white bumps that appear on the skin when keratin becomes trapped beneath the surface. These bumps are usually found around the eyes, nose, and cheeks.
diseases.symptoms: Small, white or yellowish cysts on the skin, typically painless and non-itchy.
diseases.treatment: Treatment for milia includes using exfoliating skincare products, professional extraction, and topical retinoids to promote cell turnover.

diseases.name: Rosacea
diseases.description: Rosacea is a chronic skin condition characterized by facial redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes acne-like bumps.
symptoms: Bumps and pimples on the face.

diseases.name: Unknown_Normal
diseases.description: Normal skin with no observable disease or abnormalities.
